awd_titl_txt: COVID-19 Science in Support of Local Decision-Making
awd_abstract_narration:
COVID-19 continues to pose a daunting challenge that requires effective use of science to manage community response and recovery. The goals of this project are to apply community engagement principles in a series of virtual workshops hosted in partnership with local communities around Washington State that will respond directly to local needs for scientific discourse about COVID-19. These workshops will facilitate the exchange of knowledge and sharing of experiences in science-informed decision making and help local scientists understand how to apply their expertise to inform decisionmakers. The outcomes of this project will increase the understanding of how to use local-level science-for-policy discourse to address critical issues within and beyond the current pandemic management and recovery across the state and the country.

This project centers around a series of virtual workshops co-designed and co-created with local decisionmakers, community leaders, and participating scientists in diverse parts of Washington State. These workshops will be designed to cultivate cross-sector and multidisciplinary dialogues with scientists and local communities about key issues identified by community leaders related to the COVID-19 pandemic response and recovery. This project will advance knowledge in participatory design and public engagement around science for policy. The project’s co-design and engagement processes will create a replicable approach for providing greater science-for-policy discourse and innovation at the state and local levels.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
It has never been more important to integrate science effectively and sensitively into public discourse and decision-making. The COVID-19 pandemic has had widespread effects throughout every aspect of life and society. The pandemic response has required leaders in every sector and at national, state and local levels to take in information and assess options and tradeoffs to make decisions. This can be an extraordinary challenge in the face of a constantly evolving situation. Effective use of science continues to be needed to manage and recover from the COVID-19 pandemic. Community engagement expands the societal benefits of science by increasing the usefulness of scientific results, the application of science to inform policy, and the effectiveness of science communication.

The Washington State Academy of Sciences (WSAS) hosted virtual workshops co-designed and co-created with local decisionmakers, community leaders, and participating scientists in diverse parts of Washington State. The workshops cultivated cross-sector and multidisciplinary dialogues with scientists and local communities about key issues identified by community leaders related to the COVID-19 pandemic response and recovery. The dialogue events and their planning process facilitated the exchange of knowledge and sharing of experiences, to the benefit of communities, local decisionmakers, and local scientists.

One workshop, a dialogue with communities in Spokane, WA, considered ?How can a community grow in ways that enhance health?? The other dialogue with Coastal Washington communities investigated ?How does housing contribute to a thriving community?? The topics, panels, and questions were derived directly from the input of community members and participants. Throughout each dialogue event, panelists fielded questions and built on or responded to each other?s statements, often highlighting the interconnectedness of the issues at hand and bringing in the context of broader social issues,

The outcomes of the workshop series were:

  • Increased awareness among decisionmakers about emerging science relevant for local decision-making.
  • Increased awareness among scientists of state and local needs for scientific information.
  • Thoughtful dialogue focused on interconnectedness and shared community experiences.
  • Refined community engagement activities and processes that can be further developed as infrastructure to deepen the ongoing use of science in support of local needs, across the U.S.
  • Formation of new collaborations that persist after the workshop series, which enhance the use of science in local problem-solving.

More about the participants and the content of the discussions can be in summaries produced by WSAS: https://washacad.org/covid-19-community-dialogues/. Community planning partners were integral to disseminating the results of the workshops with their networks. The broader impacts of this project were improved science communication and expansion of the societal benefits of scientific activity. These impacts were achieved through the dialogue process, which facilitated the exchange of knowledge and sharing of experiences among researchers and community members with different types of expertise and experience. In addition to reaching the those who attended the events, the impact of the dialogue planning process catalyzed connections within communities, and across sectors and roles.

Our work advanced knowledge in participatory design and public engagement around science for policy. WSAS has developed an adaptable framework for further engagement and co-design processes, resulting in a replicable approach for building new relationships and providing greater science-for-policy discourse at the local level. This approach can be applied in future activities in response to the needs of communities across Washington State and the nation to find science-based solutions to challenging issues.
